Question_1.Context: The study focused on determining the mechanical material properties of healthy porcine myocardium in three regions: left ventricle (LV), mid-wall/interventricular septum (MDW), and right ventricle (RV).
Question_1.Question: What is the main objective of the study?
Question_1.A: To determine the mechanical material properties of unhealthy porcine myocardium.
Question_1.B: To develop new therapies for heart diseases.
Question_1.C: To determine the mechanical material properties of healthy porcine myocardium in three regions.
Question_1.D: To study the mechanical properties of the human heart.
Question_1.Source: Hence, the main objective of this paper is to determine the mechanical material properties of healthy porcine myocardium in three regions, namely left ventricle (LV), mid-wall/interventricular septum (MDW) and right ventricle (RV).

Question_2.Context: The study involved conducting biaxial testing on the LV, MW, and RV regions of the pig heart.
Question_2.Question: What type of testing was conducted on the pig heart regions?
Question_2.Source: Biaxial testing in the LV, MW and RV was conducted.

Question_3.Context: The study compared the fit of two constitutive models, the Fung model and the Choi-Vito model, to the experimental data.
Question_3.Question: Which constitutive model provided the best fit to the experimental data?
Question_3.C: Both models provided an equally good fit
Question_3.D: None of the models provided a good fit
Question_3.Source: The Choi-Vito model was found to provide the best fit with the experimental data compared to the Fung model.

Question_4.Context: The study found differences in material properties between the left ventricle (LV), mid-wall/interventricular septum (MDW), and right ventricle (RV) of the pig heart.
Question_4.Question: What was observed regarding the material properties of the three heart regions?
Question_4.A: They were assumed to be the same.
Question_4.B: They were found to be homogeneous.
Question_4.D: They were not studied in the experiment.
Question_4.Source: This study shows that the mechanical behaviour of porcine myocardial tissue is non-linear and anisotropic.

Question_5.Context: The study emphasized the importance of accurate computational models for studying various heart diseases.
Question_5.Question: What role do computational models play in understanding heart diseases?
Question_5.A: They are not useful for studying heart diseases.
Question_5.B: They are essential for developing new therapies.
Question_5.C: They have no impact on understanding heart diseases.
Question_5.D: They are only used for surgical procedures.
Question_5.Source: Computational modelling is increasingly utilised to further understand pathological conditions. Various new interventions and therapies have been developed based on knowledge gained from these computational models.

Question_6.Context: The study highlighted the importance of accurately determining the mechanical properties of the heart regions.
Question_6.Question: Why is it important to accurately determine the mechanical properties of heart regions?
Question_6.A: To develop accurate computational models for studying heart diseases.
Question_6.C: To understand the physiological functions of the heart.
Question_6.D: To study the mechanical properties of soft tissues.
Question_6.Source: Inaccuracy in the mechanical properties of the heart region may affect the accuracy of the computational models developed.

Question_7.Context: The study found differences in material parameters between the RV, LV, and MDW regions of the pig heart.
Question_7.Question: What was observed regarding the anisotropy of the pig heart regions?
Question_7.D: They were not studied in the experiment.
Question_7.Source: Like various soft tissues, passive myocardium in the three different regions were found to be anisotropic.

Question_8.Context: The study compared the material parameters of the RV, LV, and MDW regions using the Fung and Choi-Vito models.
Question_8.Question: Which model showed differences in material parameters between the RV and LV regions?
Question_8.Source: For the Choi-Vito model, the differences in anisotropy between the RV and LV were found to be insignificant.

Question_9.Context: The study discussed the implications of regional differences in material properties of the pig heart.
Question_9.Question: What implications do regional differences in material properties have?
Question_9.B: May affect the accuracy of computational models.
Question_9.Source: Inaccuracy in the mechanical properties of the heart region may affect the accuracy of the computational models developed.

Question_10.Context: The study highlighted the importance of using accurate material parameters in finite element analysis for studying heart diseases.
Question_10.Question: What can accurate material parameters be used for in finite element analysis?
Question_10.B: To study the physiological functions of the heart.
Question_10.C: To understand the mechanical properties of soft tissues.
Question_10.D: To study the mechanisms of heart diseases.
Question_10.Source: An average Fung and Choi-Vito model in three different pig heart regions could be employed for the development of computational models as listed in Tables 4 and 8.
